qas.question: What acronym was the Music Corporation of America known by?
Where did MCA's Revue Productions subsidiary rent space?
In square kilometers, how large was the lot Universal sold to MCA?
In what year did Universal sell its 360-acre lot to MCA?
How much did MCA pay for Universal's 360-acre lot?

plausible_answers.text: The combination of the studio/theater-chain break-up and the rise of television

qas.question: What was responsible for a rise in audience for cinema productions?
When did Universal sell its 1.5-acre studio lot?
How much did Universal sell its lot to MAC for?
What did MAC not own after the lot purchase?

context: By the late 1950s, the motion picture business was again changing. <b5_0>The combination of the studio/theater-chain break-up and the rise of television<b5_0/> saw the reduced audience size for cinema productions. <b6_0>The Music Corporation of America<b6_0/> (<a0_0>MCA<a0_0/>), then predominately a talent agency, had also become a powerful television producer, renting space at <a1_0>Republic Studios<a1_0/> for its Revue Productions subsidiary. After a period of complete shutdown, a moribund Universal agreed to sell its 360-acre (<a2_0>1.5<a2_0/> km²) studio lot to MCA in <a3_0><b7_0>1958<b7_0/><a3_0/>, for <a4_0><b8_0>$11 million<b8_0/><a4_0/>, renamed Revue Studios. MCA owned the studio lot, but not <b9_0>Universal Pictures<b9_0/>, yet was increasingly influential on Universal's product. The studio lot was upgraded and modernized, while MCA clients like Doris Day, Lana Turner, Cary Grant, and director Alfred Hitchcock were signed to Universal Pictures contracts.
